text: <@U22PWJ41G> <@U22PNRAJD>

Thanks for the feedback. We have thought about single v. commercial(multi-use) licensing and certainly can see the benefit, for both the provider and end user. We do not have 2018 plans to implement this but it is worth noting that this is a topic of conversation and we are aware of the issue. Thanks!

Thanks for the info <@U22PNRAJD> - Are there terms of purchase somewhere that I’m not seeing that detail the use / modification rights of any given template? (ex: somewhere i can see the licenses explicitly defined vs just implied by the template existing on a given portal?)
Currently the only place to see this is when a user hovers over the purchase button. There is a message that states “Includes one license for <http://xxx.com|xxx.com>”.
Some have that, some don’t (I didn’t check all but I assume anything paid has that disclaimer?) Free templates == free use / re-use / re-sale?
Both free and paid have this disclaimer. Free= Did not cost money. If have an example of MKPL listing that does not have this that would be helpful.
Maybe you’re right and I was imagining not seeing the disclaimer - If I come across one without I will DM you - thanks for the info!
Cool. Thanks. Bottomline, we can do better here. I dream of a single and commercial license option with the ability to also sell services when an assets in purchased. Once can dream…

I agree, there’s a lot of really nice things that can be done with the marketplace (modules opens up a whole realm of possibilities) and the idea of including services WITH a purchase is quite appetizing from a new retainer / lead-gen perspective
<!channel> is this the right channel for Job Opportunities?  If not, where would be the best channel to post?
to be clear, I’m looking for devs to collaborate with our team
This channel is about submitting modules to the HubSpot Template and Module Marketplace. Perhaps <#C22PJ878V|random>?
Or <#C22PU4LV8|general>
In any case, please do not use @-here or @-channel which notifies 484 people of your message
Unless the goal is to alert everyone about something :thinking_face:
Slack has got to have some way to make it so only admins can use that, or something
it already shows a warning when you try to use @-channel, so you have to confirm use of it

it should just pop up very obviously “You are about to message 484 people, these people will reply with ‘hey! no @-channel or here, that’s rude’ if you are prepared to get pinged for the next 20 minutes about it, hit  “I’m okay wit that!”
Just disabled the use of @-here or @-channel.
Sorry all, didn’t mean to annoy
I’ll shoot for General
sorry about that.
:cricket::cricket:
seriously, beyond inproper use of spamming with @- channel is there any information being exchanged?
I’m aware of what’s not happening.  Looking to find out what is happening without emailing one on one. <@U7SL518D6> how are you staying informed.  1:1 emails with people?  DM’s?

Mostly just being active in the slack. The more active you are the more other people share what they know, and the HS staff share what they know when they are allowed to. It’s pretty common when the HS team wants to get people to test out new features and whatnot they either broadcast it in the slack channels, or occasionally direct message people they’ve felt have given good feedback in the past. I have also gotten direct emails from some of the HS team in this slack(usually invites to weigh in on something or to an event).

I also attended a Chicago HubSpot User Group last month which was pretty great, <@U6GNQ7JBU> gave a great presentation about everything HubSpot is doing to improve performance for HS sites, and some of the awesome things developers will get to take advantage of.

I would say largely this slack is the best place for info. <@U22PKFRU5> has been talking about doing a developer blog, with email subscriptions.
